https://jenkins.openbmc.org/job/ci-repository/59027/ : SUCCESS

I am not following what this single #include is doing for us.

I'm also surprised that clang-format didn't get upset with you now having the headers out of order.  Is something broken in this repository with clang-format?

clang-format is used for cpp and hpp files, before pushing the patches.
controller.hpp is direct header of controller.cpp. Therefore, it is added at the top of this file and other headers are added in the order.
Is this inheritance really necessary?  Can you just put the content right into the underlying object?

I think you misunderstood.  My question was why bother with this whole abstraction?  Why have a Controller class that inherits from a InternalInterface class?  Why not just implement the controller directly?

LED methods are declared in InternalInterface class and it will be defined in the Controller Class. The definition for addLed and removeLed method will be added in the controller class as a new patches in the future. Therefore, it is inherited in the controller class.

> LED methods are declared in InternalInterface class and it will be defined in the Controller Class.

This doesn't answer the question of _why_?  Why bother with inheritance for a single instance?  It seems like extra clutter.

This approach is based on the reference from the phosphor-power repository. Abstract method is used to declare the method name in the interface class and therefore, it is override in the another class to define the method.

https://github.com/openbmc/phosphor-power/blob/master/phosphor-regulators/src/manager.hpp#L42
https://github.com/openbmc/phosphor-power/blob/master/phosphor-regulators/src/interfaces/manager_interface.cpp
I'll let Andrew decide then.  It seems excessive to me.

I don't think it quite makes sense either. We should implement things in terms of what our immediate requirements are. We don't have a requirement to extend this behaviour through inheritance and virtual methods, so I'm with Patrick here: we should just implement it in a single class regardless of what phosphor-power are doing (who might have different requirements).

The key point of the phosphor-power example was that they implemented DBus behaviour for an internal interface without relying on sdbusplus code generation.

Done

Implementation is done under a single class for LED methods and submitted the patchset.

I don't think we can submit these patches until this is sorted out? Or have I misunderstood?

Also, given that, I'd prefer we squash this into the previous patch so we keep things coherent.
"Therefore" isn't quite the right word here. I think you want to say "We switch to"?
Again, please demonstrate what you actually did, not just assert that you did something.
Hi Jayashree. This looks okay aside from a couple of cleanups needed in the commit message.
I'm going to squash this one into the previous patch so the transformation is atomic.
